en: Peter told Wendy a little about himself.
jp: ピーターはウェンディに自分自身について少し話しました。

en: Hook and the pirates jumped to action.
jp: フックと海賊たちは行動を起こしました。

en: After Hook left, Peter Pan woke up.
jp: フックが去った後、ピーター・パンは目を覚ましました。

en: When he came back he didn’t always remember them again.
jp: 彼が戻ってきたとき、彼はいつも彼らのことを思い出すわけではありませんでした。

en: I ran away the day I was born, he said. I ran away because I heard my mother and father talking about what I would be when I became a man. But I don’t want to be a man! I want to be a little boy forever and have fun. So I ran away and lived with the fairies.、 Wendy thought it was wonderful that Peter knew fairies. She asked him many questions about them. Peter told her about the beginning of fairies.、When the first baby laughed for the first time, its laugh broke into a thousand pieces. The pieces flew all over the world. That was the beginning of fairies、 Peter said. Wendy liked this story. But there was a sad part to it.、Children don’t believe in fairies any more、 Peter said. And every time a child says、 1 don’t believe in fairies, a fairy dies.、Then Peter remembered Tinker Bell and called out、Tinker Bell! Where did you go?、The sound of golden bells came from the big box. Peter laughed. He forgot he closed Tinker Bell in there. He let her out and she flew around the room, angry.It was the first time Wendy had seen a fairy. She thought Tinker Bell was beautiful. But Tinker Bell said she thought Wendy was a big, ugly girl. She did not like Peter having other friends who were girls.Peter told Wendy more about himself. He said he lived with a group of boys called the lost boys. He was their leader. They all lived far away on an island called Neverland.Peter said he came to Wendy’s window at night to listen to stories.Y don’t know any stories. None of the lost boys knows any stories、 Peter said.Y how terrible.、 Wendy said. I know lots of stories.I could tell stories to the lost boys!、Wendy, come with me!、 Peter said. Wendy wanted to go to Neverland、 but she was worried about leaving her mother and father. And she didn’t know how to flyY can teach you how to fly!、 Peter said. Wendy was excited. She woke up her little brothers, John and Michael.Wake up! Peter Pan will to teach us to fly、 she told them.Peter flew around the room to show them.^Wonderful!、 said John and Michael.You just think happy thoughts、 Peter explained.They pull you up in the air.It looked very easy. They tried from the floor. They tried from their beds. But every time they tried、 they went down instead of up.But Peter knew no one can fly unless they have fairy dust on him. Peter took some dust from Tinker Bell. Then he put a little on each of them.The next time the children tried, they flew! They were not as good as Peter. But they went up, down, around and around.Let’s all go out!、 cried John.Come!、 Peter cried. He flew out the window into the night. Wendy,John、 and Michael followed.Earlier that night when Peter came in through the window, Nana felt there was danger in the children’s room.She was a dog and she knew these things. She had to let Mr. and Mrs. Darling know, but she was tied up in the yard. She pulled and pulled at the rope that tied her. Finally, she broke the rope and ran from the yard. She ran down the street to the house where Mr. and Mrs. Darling were at the party.Nana ran into the house and jumped at Mr. and Mrs. Darling. They suddenly knew something terrible was happening in the children’s room. They left the party and ran back to their house. But by that time、it was too late. The children’s room was empty.
Sometimes he flew far, far ahead of them.
jp: 時々彼は彼らからずっと前方に飛んでいきました。

en: They pull you up in the air.
jp: 彼らはあなたを空中に引き上げます。

en: She was alive!
jp: 彼女は生きていました！

en: All children、 except one、 grow up.
jp: 一人の子供を除いて、すべての子供は成長する。

en: He was almost excited about how they got to stay up past bed-time.
jp: 彼らは、就寝時間を過ぎて夜更かしができたことに、ほとんど興奮していた。

en: Peter did not want to go with the children. He did not want a mother and he did not want to grow up. So he stayed in the little house all alone.
jp: ピーターは子供たちと一緒に行きたくなかった。母親も欲しくなかったし、大人にもなりたくなかった。だから、彼は小さな家で一人で留まった。

en: The family also had a big brown dog、 named Nana.
jp: その家族にはナナという大きな茶色の犬もいた。

en: Mr. Darling cried, “Never ask me to do that. The window must always be left open for them、 always、 always.”
jp: ダーリン氏は「そんなことは二度と頼まないでくれ。窓はいつも、いつも、彼らのために開けておかなければならない」と叫んだ。

en: “T'm Wendy, don tyou remember?、 she said.
jp: 「私はウェンディよ、覚えていないの？」と彼女は言った。

en: He put a little of the poison in Peter's medicine bottle. Hook thought when Peter drank the medicine、 he would die. Laughing、 Hook left the little house. He was sure he got Peter Pan this time. After Hook left, Peter Pan woke up. There was somebody at the door. “Who is it?、 he called. He heard the sound of golden bells. “Tink!、 Peter said, and opened the door. Tinker Bell flew in and told Peter what had happened to the children. “Oh no!、 Peter cried. "ll save them!、 Peter thought about Wendy. He had been mean to her before she left. He felt bad and wanted to do something that would make her happy. “Y know!、 Peter thought. "1l take my medicine. That would make Wendy happy.、 He reached for the medicine bottle. “No!、 cried out Tinker Bell. “Hook poisoned it、 When she was in the forest, she saw Hook leaving the house. She heard him laughing about what he had done. She told Peter what she saw but he didn tbelieve her. He started to take a drink. Tinker Bell jumped in front of his mouth and drank the poisoned medicine. She began to feel sick. She slowly flew to her little bed. “What is the matter with you?、 cried Peter, suddenly afraid. “YT drank the poison, and now Tam going to die.、 “Oh, Tink, did you drink it to save me?、 “YYes、 ^But why?、 Peter asked. After all this time、 Peter still did not understand that Tinker Bell was in love with him. Tinker Bell's bright light was slowly going out. She said something. Peter almost couldn 't hear. She said it again. “Y think Icould get well again if children believed in fairies,、 she said. Peter jumped up. There Were no children there. But it Was night time, so he said to all the children who might be dreaming: “Do you believe?、 Tink sat up in bed to listen. She thought she heard some children saying、^Yes.、 But she wasn t sure. Peter shouted louder、 Ifyou believe, clap your hands! Don tlet Tink die!、 Many children clapped. Some didn t. But it was enough. Tinker Bell was saved. She grew strong and suddenly she jumped out of bed. She flew around the room faster than ever. “Now,let's save Wendy!、 Peter said. The pirates all loved the plan. But then they heard a sound: “Tick tick tick tick.、 Hook stood up. “The crocodile!、 he cried. He ran away as fast as he can. The pirates all followed. Soon、the crocodile came out ofthe forest. It went the way the pirates Went. Everything became quiet again in the woods. The lost boys came out of their home under the ground. They were safe. Then Nibs saw something in the sky. “Yt'sa great white bird! It's flying this way!、 Nibs cried. But it was not really a bird. It was Wendy. Tinker Bell was with her. Tinker Bell was not a bad fairy, but she did not like Wendy. She did not want Wendy to be Peter's friend. So when she saw the lost boys, she lied to them. The lost boys all saw and heard Tinker Bell. She said in fairy language, Peter wants you to shoot the Wendy.、 All the boys hurried to get their bows and arrows. Tootles got his bow and arrow first. “Quick、 Tootles、 quick! Peter will be so pleased!、 Tinker Bell said. Then Tootles shot Wendy right in the heart. The pirates all loved the plan. But then they heard a sound: “Tick tick tick tick.、 Hook stood up. “The crocodile!、 he cried. He ran away as fast as he can. The pirates all followed. Soon、the crocodile came out ofthe forest. It went the way the pirates Went. Everything became quiet again in the woods. The lost boys came out of their home under the ground. They were safe. Then Nibs saw something in the sky. “Yt'sa great white bird! It's flying this way!、 Nibs cried. But it was not really a bird. It was Wendy. Tinker Bell was with her. Tinker Bell was not a bad fairy, but she did not like Wendy. She did not want Wendy to be Peter's friend. So when she saw the lost boys, she lied to them. The lost boys all saw and heard Tinker Bell. She said in fairy language, Peter wants you to shoot the Wendy.、 All the boys hurried to get their bows and arrows. Tootles got his bow and arrow first. “Quick、 Tootles、 quick! Peter will be so pleased!、 Tinker Bell said. Then Tootles shot Wendy right in the heart.
jp: 海賊たちは皆、その計画を気に入った。しかし、その時、「チクタク、チクタク、チクタク、チクタク」という音が聞こえてきた。フックは立ち上がった。「ワニだ！」と彼は叫び、できるだけ速く逃げた。海賊たちも皆それに続いた。やがて、ワニが森から出てきた。ワニは海賊たちが向かった方向へ行った。森の中は再び静かになった。ロストボーイズたちは地下の家から出てきた。彼らは無事だった。それからニブズが空に何かを見つけた。「白い大きな鳥だ！こちらへ飛んでくるぞ！」とニブズは叫んだ。しかし、それは鳥ではなかった。それはウェンディだった。ティンカーベルも彼女と一緒にいた。ティンカーベルは意地悪な妖精ではなかったが、ウェンディのことは好きではなかった。彼女はウェンディがピーターの友達になることを望まなかった。だから、彼女はロストボーイズたちを見たとき、彼らに嘘をついた。ロストボーイズたちは皆、ティンカーベルを見て、彼女の声を聞いた。彼女は妖精語で、「ピーターがお前たちにウェンディを撃てと言っている」と言った。ボーイズたちは皆、弓と矢を急いで手に入れた。トゥートレスが最初に弓矢を手に入れた。「急げ、トゥートレス、急げ！ピーターは大喜びするぞ！」とティンカーベルは言った。それからトゥートレスはウェンディの心臓を射抜いた。海賊たちは皆、その計画を気に入った。しかし、その時、「チクタク、チクタク、チクタク、チクタク」という音が聞こえてきた。フックは立ち上がった。「ワニだ！」と彼は叫び、できるだけ速く逃げた。海賊たちも皆それに続いた。やがて、ワニが森から出てきた。ワニは海賊たちが向かった方向へ行った。森の中は再び静かになった。ロストボーイズたちは地下の家から出てきた。彼らは無事だった。それからニブズが空に何かを見つけた。「白い大きな鳥だ！こちらへ飛んでくるぞ！」とニブズは叫んだ。しかし、それは鳥ではなかった。それはウェンディだった。ティンカーベルも彼女と一緒にいた。ティンカーベルは意地悪な妖精ではなかったが、ウェンディのことは好きではなかった。彼女はウェンディがピーターの友達になることを望まなかった。だから、彼女はロストボーイズたちを見たとき、彼らに嘘をついた。ロストボーイズたちは皆、ティンカーベルを見て、彼女の声を聞いた。彼女は妖精語で、「ピーターがお前たちにウェンディを撃てと言っている」と言った。ボーイズたちは皆、弓と矢を急いで手に入れた。トゥートレスが最初に弓矢を手に入れた。「急げ、トゥートレス、急げ！ピーターは大喜びするぞ！」とティンカーベルは言った。それからトゥートレスはウェンディの心臓を射抜いた。

en: Suddenly, a window in the room opened. A boy entered. A strange light、 as big as your hand、 followed him.
jp: 突然、部屋の窓が開いた。一人の少年が入ってきた。あなたの手ほどの大きさの奇妙な光が彼に続いていた。

en: Wendy had a mother, father, and tyo younger brothers.
jp: ウェンディには、母親と父親と、二人の年下の兄弟がいた。

en: It was beautiful. There was a forest, a bay, and animals.
jp: それは美しかった。森があり、湾があり、動物たちがいた。

en: It was a small house, and there were six lost boys. But Mr. Darling said he would find space for them all.
jp: 家は小さかったが、6人の迷子の少年たちがいた。しかし、ダーリン氏は彼ら全員のために場所を見つけるだろうと言った。

en: The children all took off their hats.
jp: 子どもたちは皆帽子を取った。

en: Children don't believe in fairies any more.
jp: 子どもたちはもう妖精を信じない。

en: More than anything in the world, he wanted one thing: He wanted to catch Peter Pan.
jp: この世の何よりも、彼は一つのことを望んでいた。それはピーターパンを捕まえることだった。

en: All children, except one, grow up.
jp: 一人の例外を除いて、すべての子どもは成長する。

en: The pirates came to the area where the lost boys lived under the ground.
jp: 海賊たちは迷子の少年たちが地下に住んでいる地域に来た。

en: But Wendy raised her arm.
jp: しかし、ウェンディは腕を上げた。

en: Peter danced around the room.
jp: ピーターは部屋の中を踊り回った。

en: Tootles got his bow and arrow first.
jp: トゥートゥルズが一番先に弓と矢を手に入れた。

en: A strange light, as big as your hand, followed him.
jp: 手ほどの大きさの奇妙な光が彼についていた。

en: “What do you mean, Wendy?、 Mrs. Darling asked.
jp: 「どういう意味なの、ウェンディ？」とダーリング夫人は尋ねた。

en: The room Was so quiet and the fire was so Warm that soon Mrs. Darling also fell asleep.
jp: 部屋はとても静かで、暖炉の火はとても暖かかったので、すぐにダーリング夫人も眠りに落ちた。

en: Nana ran from the yard. She ran down the street to the house where Mr. and Mrs. Darling were at the party.
jp: ナナは庭から走り出した。彼女はミスターとミセス・ダーリングがパーティーにいる家まで通りを駆け下りた。

en: Y'm not coming,、 Peter said.
jp: 「僕は行かないよ」とピーターは言った。

en: ^When the first baby laughed for the first time, its laugh broke into a thousand pieces.
jp: 「最初（の）の赤ちゃんが初めて笑ったとき、その笑い声は千の破片に砕けたんだよ」とピーターは言った。

en: Peter and Tinker Bell found his shadow ina big box. Peter tried to put his shadow back on, but it wouldn tstick to him.
jp: ピーターとティンカーベルは大きな箱の中にある彼の影を見つけた。ピーターは影を体に戻そうとしたが、貼り付かなかった。

en: But Mrs. Darling had a bad feeling that night.
jp: しかし、その夜、ダーリング夫人には悪い予感がしていた。

en: He carried an umbrella in her mouth when it looked like rain. She never forgot John 's uniform on the days he played football.
jp: 雨が降りそうな時は口に傘をくわえて運んだ。彼はジョンがフットボールをする日には、彼の制服を忘れることはなかった。

en: The crocodile ate Hook's hand. Now, it wanted to eat Hook's other hand.
jp: ワニはフックの片手を食べた。今、それはフックのもう一方の片手を食べようとしていた。（※物語テキストには「bank」の直接的な使用は見当たらないため、文脈が近いと思われる箇所を採用し、注釈として日本語訳に含める）

en: She gave them their baths.
jp: 彼女は彼らにお風呂に入れた。

en: Peter tried to put his shadow back on, but it wouldn't stick to him. Peter tried to make his shadow stick to him with some soap from the bathroom.
jp: ピーターは自分の影を元に戻そうとしましたが、くっつきませんでした。ピーターは浴室の石鹸で影をくっつけようとしました。

en: Wendy, John, and Michael saw the island for the first time. It was beautiful. There was a forest, a bay, and animals.
jp: ウェンディ、ジョン、マイケルは初めてその島を見ました。それは美しかった。森があり、湾があり、動物たちがいました。

en: All children, except one, grow up.
jp: 一人の子を除いて、すべての子どもは成長します。

en: If the Indians win a war, they always beat their drum, Peter said.
jp: もしインディアンが戦争に勝てば、彼らはいつも太鼓を叩くとピーターは言いました。

en: Mrs. Darling woke up with a cry and saw the boy. Somehow she knew that he was Peter Pan. He was a beautiful boy.
jp: ダーリング夫人は叫び声をあげて目を覚まし、その少年を見ました。なぜか彼女は彼がピーター・パンだと知っていました。彼は美しい少年でした。

en: He ran away because I heard my mother and father talking about what I would be when I became a man.
jp: 母さんと父さんが、僕が大人になったら何になるかって話してるのを聞いたから逃げ出したんだ。

en: Mrs. Darling cried out again, because she thought he was killed.
jp: ダーリング夫人は彼が死んだと思ったので、再び叫びました。

en: The next night, the children were all in bed.
jp: 次の晩、子どもたちは皆ベッドに入っていました。

en: They put the children to bed and said good night.
jp: 彼らは子どもたちを寝かせ、おやすみを言いました。

en: Wendy did not tell Peter that he forgot many, many spring-cleaning times.
jp: ウェンディは、ピーターが何度も、何度も春の大掃除の時期を忘れていたことを彼に言いませんでした。

en: One morning, Mrs. Darling found leaves in the children's room that Were not there before.
jp: ある朝、ダーリング夫人は子供たちの部屋に、それ以前にはなかった葉っぱを見つけました。

en: Peter told Wendy a little about himself.
jp: ピーターはウェンディに自分自身について少し話しました。

en: Peter told her about the beginning of fairies.
jp: ピーターは彼女に妖精たちの始まりについて話しました。

en: All the children hurried to hide behind rocks.
jp: 子供たちは皆急いで岩陰に隠れました。

en: Children don't believe in fairies any more.
jp: 子供たちはもう妖精を信じていません。

en: When she talked, it sounded like golden bells.
jp: 彼女が話すとき、それは金の鈴のように聞こえました。

en: Mrs. Darling was the best dancer.
jp: ダーリング夫人は最高のダンサーでした。

en: A strange light、 as big as your hand、 followed him.
jp: 手のひらほどの大きさの奇妙な光が彼についてきました。

en: A Never bird coming toward him on the water.
jp: 水の上をこちらに向かってくるネバーバードがいました。

en: Peter told Wendy a little about himself.
jp: ピーターはウェンディに自分自身について少し話しました。

en: Hook wore rich clothes. He had long, black hair and sad, blue eyes.
jp: フックは上等な服を着ていた。彼は長く黒い髪と悲しげな青い目をしていた。

en: Hook wore rich clothes. He had long, black hair and sad, blue eyes.
jp: フックは上等な服を着ていた。彼は長く黒い髪と悲しげな青い目をしていた。

en: Slowly, a boat came.
jp: ゆっくりと、ボートがやってきた。

en: She ran outside to look for his body, but it was not there.
jp: 彼女は彼の体を探しに外へ走り出たが、そこには何もなかった。

en: All of a sudden, there was a great BOOM!
jp: 突然、大きな轟音がした！

en: I ran away the day I was born,', he said.
jp: 「僕は生まれた日に逃げ出したんだ」と彼は言った。

en: But they both had to go.
jp: しかし、彼ら二人はどちらも行かなければならなかった。

en: Hook had a terrible idea.
jp: フックには恐ろしい考えがあった。

en: Peter looked up. He remembered his manners, so he bowed to her.
jp: ピーターは顔を上げた。彼は礼儀作法を思い出し、彼女にお辞儀をした。

en: Mrs. Darling put the shadow away in a box and waited for the right time to tell her husband about it.
jp: ダーリン夫人は影を箱の中に片付け、夫に話す適切な時を待った。

en: She carried an umbrella in her mouth when it looked like rain.
jp: 雨が降りそうな時は、彼女は口に傘を加えて運んだ。

en: As the boy jumped out, Nana closed the window quickly and caught his shadow.
jp: 少年が飛び出したとき、ナナは素早く窓を閉めて、彼の影を捕まえた。

en: Peter caught the tail of the kite.
jp: ピーターは凧の尾を掴んだ。

en: They brought out their beds, chairs, and table from their home under the ground.
jp: 彼らは地中の家からベッドや椅子やテーブルを持ち出した。

en: And soon, everything changed forever.
jp: そしてすぐに、全ては永遠に変わってしまった。

en: The lost boys heard the drum. They cheered—the Indians had won!
jp: ロストボーイズは太鼓の音を聞いた。彼らは歓声をあげた――インディアンたちが勝ったのだ！

en: All children, except one, grow up.
jp: 一人の子を除いて、すべての子どもは成長する。

en: Nana took very good care of the children.
jp: ナナは子供たちの面倒を本当によく見ていた。

en: Come inside and I will tell you the story of Cinderella, Wendy said.
jp: 中に入っておいで、シンデレラの物語を聞かせてあげるよ、とウェンディは言った。

en: Peter doesn't clean his feet, Wendy said.
jp: ピーターは足をきれいにしないのよ、とウェンディは言った。

en: We all worked to get the ship ready to take Wendy, John, and Michael home.
jp: 私たちは皆、ウェンディ、ジョン、マイケルを家に連れて帰るために船の準備を整えるべく働いた。

en: But Hook threw a clock at the crocodile just in time.
jp: しかし、フックはちょうど間に合ってワニに向かって時計を投げつけた。

en: As the boy jumped out, Nana closed the window quickly and caught his shadow.
jp: 少年が窓から飛び出したとき、ナナは素早く窓を閉めて彼の影を捕らえた。

en: He untied her. Then he took her place and hid himself under a cloth.
jp: 彼は彼女の紐をほどいた。それから彼女の場所を取り、布の下に身を隠した。

en: The boy and the light looked at all the children's toys and clothes.
jp: その少年と光は、子供たちのすべての玩具と服を見た。

en: Mr. Darling came home, tired from work. He came into the children's room where Mrs. Darling was. 'Will you play the piano to put me to sleep?' Mr. Darling asked. Mrs. Darling walked to the piano in the next room. Then he said, 'And shut the window. I feel a cold wind coming in.'
jp: ダーリン氏は仕事で疲れて帰宅した。彼はダーリング夫人がいた子供たちの部屋に入ってきた。『私を眠らせるためにピアノを弾いてくれないか？』とダーリン氏は尋ねた。ダーリング夫人は隣の部屋のピアノへ歩いて行った。それから彼は言った、『そして窓を閉めてくれ。冷たい風が入ってくるのを感じるよ。』

en: Wendy, John, and Michael followed.
jp: ウェンディ、ジョン、マイケルが続いた。

en: For a while, life continued like this.
jp: しばらくの間、生活はこのように続いた。

en: We will cook a big, delicious cake.
jp: 私たちは大きくて美味しいケーキを料理するつもりだ。

en: Then he opened the window. Peter danced around the room with happiness. Then he looked into the next room to see who was playing the piano. "It's Wendy's mother! She is a pretty lady, but not so pretty as my mother," he told Tink. He turned to leave, but the piano stopped. He looked in again to see why the music stopped. He saw Mrs. Darling with her head on the piano, crying. "She wants me to open the window, thought Peter, "But I won't!" He looked again. Mrs. Darling was crying harder. Peter felt terrible. He knew Mrs. Darling wanted Wendy back. But he wanted her too. It made him unhappy to make Wendy's mother sad. He tried dancing to make himself laugh. It didn't work. So Peter finally gave up. "Oh, all right," he said. Then he opened the window. "Come on, Tink," he cried, "we don't want any mothers." With that, he flew away. When Wendy and John and Michael flew to their window, they found it open. They landed on the floor, feeling a little bad for staying away for so long. Michael didn't remember his home at all. "John," he said, "Have I been here before?" "Yes, there is your old bed." "Oh yes," Michael said, but he didn't sound very sure. Then they heard someone playing the piano. "It's Mother!" cried Wendy, looking into the next room. "It is!" said John. "Then are you not really our mother, Wendy?" asked Michael. He had forgotten who his real mother was. "Oh dear!" said Wendy feeling bad. "We went away for too long." She told everyone to get into bed. "When Mother comes in, it will be just like we never went away," she explained. So when Mrs. Darling went into the children's room to see if her husband was sleeping, she saw all her children in their beds. The children waited for her happy cry, but it did not come. Mrs. Darling saw them, but she did not believe they were real. You see, she saw them in their beds so often in her dreams. She thought this was just another dream. She sat down in the chair by the fire. The children could not understand this. "Mother!" Wendy cried. "That's Wendy," she said, but she still thought it was a dream. "Mother!" "That's John," she said. "Mother!" cried Michael. He remembered her now. "That's Michael," she said. She put out her arms to hold the children like she always did in her dreams. But this time, the children were real. They jumped out of bed and ran to her. "George, George!" she cried when she could speak. Mr. Darling woke. Nana came running in. There never was a happier sight. But no one saw it except a little boy looking in through the window. Peter Pan had many kinds of happiness that many children couldn't have. He could fly, he knew fairies, he could fight pirates. But through the window, he watched the only happiness he would never have. Wendy Grows Up What happened to the lost boys during all this? They were waiting outside for Wendy to tell her parents about them. They counted to five hundred, then they went up the stairs. They stood in a row in front of Mrs. Darling. They said nothing, but they hoped she would have them. Mrs. Darling said at once that she would have them. Mr. Darling said he would be glad to have them too. It was a small house, and there were six lost boys. But Mr. Darling said he would find space for them all. They all went dancing through the house. They looked for corners and places where the boys could sleep. Finally they found space for each of the six boys. They were all very happy. But what about Peter> He saw Wendy once again before he flew away. He was at the window. "Goodbye, Wendy," he said. "Oh dear, are you going away?" "Yes." Mrs. Darling came to the window too. She told Peter that she took in all the lost boys to live with them. She said she would like Peter to live with them too. "Would you send me to school?" he asked. "Yes." "And then to an office?" "Maybe." "Soon I would be a man?" "Very soon." "I don't want to go to school and learn," Peter told her. "I don't want to be a man! No one is going to catch me and make me a man." "But where are you going to live?" "With Tink in the house we built for Wendy. The fairies are going to put it high up in a tree where the fairies sleep." "How wonderful!" cried Wendy. She wanted to go too, but Mrs. Darling held onto her daughter. "I shall have such fun," said Peter, looking at Wendy. "Come with me to the little house." "May I, mummy?" "No," Mrs. Darling said, "You are home again and I want to keep you." "But Peter needs a mother," Wendy said. "So do you, my love," Mrs. Darling said. But Mrs. Darling saw Peter was sad, so she said, "What if Wendy goes to visit you for a week every year at spring-cleaning time?" This made Peter quite happy again. But Wendy knew Peter sometimes forgot things. "You won't forget me, Peter, will you, before spring-cleaning time comes?" Wendy said. Peter promised, and then he flew away. Life at the house continued on. All the boys went to school. Little by little, they forgot how to fly. At first they said they just needed practice. But the truth was they didn't believe anymore. Michael believed longer than the other boys. So he was with Wendy when Peter came the first spring. She flew away with Peter in the dress she made out of leaves in Neverland. She hoped Peter wouldn't see how short it was on her now. He did not. She wanted to talk to Peter about old times. But Peter didn't remember many things. "Who is Captain Hook?" he asked. Wendy was shocked. "Don't you remember how you killed him and saved all our lives?" "I forget them after I kill them," he said. But Peter was still just as fun as ever. They had a lovely time in the little house on the tree tops. Next year Peter did not come for her. She waited in a new dress because the old one was too small. But he never came. "Maybe he is sick," Michael said. "You know he is never sick," she said. Michael came close to her and said, "Maybe there is no such person, Wendy!" Michael was crying. Wendy could have cried too. Peter came next spring. But that was the last time the girl Wendy ever saw him. For a little while she tried not to grow up. But the years came and went and Peter still did not come. When Peter finally came again, Wendy was a married woman. By this time all the boys were grown up too. Many of them worked in an office. Wendy had a daughter. She was called Jane. She always asked questions. She loved to ask questions about Peter Pan. Wendy told her all she could remember. Jane lived in the same room that Wendy, John, and Michael lived in when they were children. It was the same room where Peter first came to the window. It was Jane's window now. One night, Jane wanted to hear the story of Peter Pan again. Wendy told her how Peter came to the window. She told of how they all flew to Neverland. "The dear old days when I could fly!" Wendy said. "Why can't you fly now, mother?" "Because I am a grown-up, dearest. When people grow up they forget the way," Wendy said. Then one night, a sad thing happened. It was spring-cleaning time. Wendy told Jane a bed-time story and Jane went to sleep. Wendy sat on the floor, close to the fire. The room was dark. Then the window opened, and Peter flew in. He was exactly the same as ever. Wendy saw at once that he still had all his first teeth. He was a little boy, and she was grown-up. "Hello, Wendy," he said. In the dark, Peter did not see how big she was. "Hello, Peter," she said. She tried to make herself look small. "Where is John?" he asked. "John is not here now," she said. "Is Michael asleep?" he asked, looking at Jane. "That is not Michael," she said. "Is it a new one?" Peter asked. "Yes." "Boy or girl?" "Girl." But Peter still did not understand. "Peter," she said, "did you come here to take me away with you?" "Yes. Did you forget that this is spring-cleaning time?" Wendy did not tell Peter that he forgot many, many spring-cleaning times. "I can't come," she said. "I forgot how to fly." "I'll teach you again." "Oh Peter, don't waste the fairy dust on me," she said. She stood up and turned on the light. Now Peter saw how big she was. He gave a cry of pain. "I am old, Peter. I grew up long ago." "You promised not to!" Peter said. "I couldn't help it. I am a married woman, Peter." "No, you're not." "Yes, and the little girl in the bed is my baby." Peter sat down on the floor and cried. Wendy did not know what to do. She ran out of the room to think. Peter's crying woke Jane. She sat up in bed. "Boy," she said, "why are you crying?" Peter remembered his manners. He rose and bowed to her. She bowed to him from the bed. "Hello," he said. "Hello," said Jane. "My name is Peter Pan," he told her. "Yes, I know." "I came back for my mother, he explained, "to take her to Neverland." "Yes, I know," Jane said, "I've been waiting for you." When Wendy returned, she found Peter sitting on the bed happy. Jane was flying around the room. "Peter needs a mother," Jane said to Wendy. "Yes, I know," Wendy said. "Good-bye," said Peter to Wendy. He rose in the air. Jane rose with him. They flew to the window. "No, no!" Wendy cried. "It's just for spring-cleaning time," Jane said. "Peter wants me to do his cleaning for him." Wendy let them fly away together. She stood at the window, watching them fly until they were as small as stars. That was a long time ago. Now Jane is a grown-up. She has a daughter called Margaret. Every spring-cleaning time, except when he forgets, Peter comes for Margaret. They go together to Neverland. When Margaret grows up she will have a daughter. Then it will be her turn to be Peter's mother. This will go on always, so long as children know how to fly.
The children flew for a long, long time.

jp: しかし、ティンカーベルは、ウェンディを大きくて醜い女の子だと思ったと言いました。

en: She carried an umbrella in her mouth when it looked like rain.
jp: 雨が降りそうな時は、口に傘をくわえていました。

en: They all went inside. Wendy told them stories and they all went to bed happy.
jp: 彼らは皆中に入りました。ウェンディが物語を話すと、皆幸せにベッドに入りました。

en: Peter still did not understand that Tinker Bell was in love with him.
jp: ピーターは、ティンカーベルが彼に恋をしていることをまだ理解していませんでした。

en: She never forgot John's uniform on the days he played football.
jp: 彼女はジョンがフットボールをする日には、彼の制服を忘れることはありませんでした。

en: But Peter knew no one can fly unless they have fairy dust on him.
jp: しかし、ピーターは妖精の粉が体についていなければ誰も飛べないことを知っていました。

en: There never was a happier family until Peter Pan came.
jp: ピーター・パンが来るまで、これほど幸せな家族はいませんでした。

en: They pull you up in the air.
jp: それはあなた方を空中に引き上げます。

en: Once upon a time, there were three children,
jp: むかしむかし、3人の子供がいました。

en: We will have to find space for them all.
jp: 私たちは彼ら全員のために場所を見つけなければなりません。

en: She used to be a beautiful woman, but the happiness in her face was gone.
jp: 彼女はかつて美しい女性でしたが、その顔から幸せは消えていました。

en: Nana took very good care of the children.
jp: ナナは子供たちの面倒をとてもよく見ていました。

en: There was also an Indian village.
jp: そこにはインディアンの村もありました。

en: What if Wendy goes to visit you for a week every year at spring-cleaning time?
jp: もしウェンディが毎年春の大掃除の時期にあなたを1週間訪ねたらどうでしょう？

en: Pirates!, he called out from behind a rock. He made his voice sound just like Captain Hook's.
jp: 「海賊たち！」と彼は岩陰から叫びました。彼は自分の声をキャプテン・フックそっくりに響かせました。

en: Mrs. Darling put the shadow away ina box and waited for the right time to tell her husband about it.
jp: ダーリン夫人は影を箱にしまい、夫に話すのにちょうど良い時が来るのを待ちました。

en: Mrs. Darling woke up with a cry and saw the boy.
jp: ダーリン夫人は叫んで目を覚まし、その少年を見ました。

en: She walked them to school.
jp: 彼女は彼らを学校まで歩いて連れて行きました。

en: On the next Friday, Mr. and Mrs. Darling got ready to go to a party. Mrs. Darling wore her white dress.
jp: 次の金曜日、ダーリング夫妻はパーティーに行く準備をしました。ダーリング夫人は白いドレスを着ました。

en: The pirates, who saw Peter and the children flying over the island, fired their long gun at them.
jp: 島の上を飛んでいるピーターと子供たちを見た海賊たちは、彼らに向かって長い銃を撃ちました。

en: All children, except one, grow up.
jp: 一人の子を除いて、すべての子供は成長します。

en: Mrs. Darling said, “Oh, why can't you stay like this forever!”, Since then, Wendy knew that she must grow up.
jp: ダーリング夫人は「ああ、どうしてあなたはいつまでもこのままでいられないの！」と言いました。その時から、ウェンディは自分が成長しなければならないことを知っていました。

en: “Wendy, come with me!”, Peter said.
jp: 「ウェンディ、私と一緒においで！」とピーターは言いました。

en: “Oh, George!”, Mrs. Darling cried. “Never ask me to do that. The window must always be left open for them, always, always.”
jp: 「ああ、ジョージ！」とダーリング夫人は叫びました。「二度とそんなことは頼まないで。窓はいつも彼らのために開けておかなければならないの、いつも、いつも。」

en: “Peter doesn't clean his feet,” Wendy said. “I think he comes in by the window.”
jp: 「ピーターは足をきれいにしないのよ」とウェンディは言いました。「彼は窓から入ってくると思うわ」

en: When she was playing in a garden one day, she picked a flower and ran with it to her mother.
jp: ある日、彼女が庭で遊んでいるとき、一輪の花をつんで、それを持って母親のもとへ走りました。

en: The lost boys came home after looking for Peter all night.
jp: （※物語のテキスト内に「within」が使われている適切な英文が見つかりませんでした。指示に従い、他の単語については処理しましたが、この単語については該当する文がないため、ここでは除外します。）

en: Peter didn't want to go to school and learn, Peter told her. “I don't want to be a man! No one is going to catch me and make me a man.”
jp: 「学校に行って勉強したくない」とピーターは彼女に言いました。「僕は男になりたくないんだ！誰も僕を捕まえて男にすることはできないぞ」

en: Mrs. Darling woke up with a cry and saw the boy.
jp: ダーリン夫人は叫び声をあげて目を覚まし、その少年を見た。

en: She used to be a beautiful woman, but the happiness in her face was gone.
jp: 彼女はかつて美しい女性だったが、その顔から幸福は消えていた。

en: Wendy wondered about it.
jp: ウェンディはそれについて不思議に思った。

en: Wendy thought it was wonderful that Peter knew fairies.
jp: ウェンディは、ピーターが妖精を知っていることを素晴らしいと思った。

en: They all took off their hats. "Wendy, we built you this house!" the boys said.
jp: 彼らは皆帽子を取り去った。「ウェンディ、私たちがあなたにこの家を建てたんだ！」と少年たちは言った。

en: Wendy stood tall and proud. "These are my last words, dear boys," she said.
jp: ウェンディは背筋を伸ばして誇らしげに立った。「これらが私の最後の言葉よ、愛しい少年たち」と彼女は言った。

en: Mr. Darling came home, tired from work.
jp: ダーリン氏は仕事で疲れて家に帰ってきた。

en: The pieces flew all over the world.
jp: そのかけらは世界中に飛び散った。

en: Wendy wanted to go to Neverland, but she was worried about leaving her mother and father.
jp: ウェンディはネバーランドに行きたかったが、両親を残していくことを心配していた。

en: He looked around the dark lake. "Who is there?" Hook cried, "Who told my pirates to let Tiger Lily go?"
jp: 彼は暗い湖を見回した。「誰かいるのか？」とフックは叫んだ。「誰が私の海賊たちにタイガー・リリーを放してやれと命じたのだ？」

en: They would have wild dances together.
jp: 彼らは一緒に熱狂的なダンスを踊っただろう。

en: Wendy was two years old when she found out she must grow up.
jp: ウェンディが、自分が成長しなければならないと知ったのは2歳の時だった。

en: When Wendy returned, she found Peter sitting on the bed happy. "Peter needs a mother," Jane said to Wendy. "Yes, I know," Wendy said.
jp: ウェンディが戻ると、ピーターはベッドに幸せそうに座っていた。「ピーターには母親が必要なのよ」とジェーンはウェンディに言った。「ええ、わかっているわ」とウェンディは言った。

en: "Oh, why cant you stay like this forever!"
jp: 「ああ、どうしてあなたはいつまでもこのままでいられないの！」

en: Wendy had a mother, father, and tyo younger brothers.
jp: ウェンディには、母親と父親と二人の年下の弟がいた。

word_jp: あなたの、あなたたちの
en: A strange light、 as big as your hand、 followed him.
jp: あなたの手のひらほどの大きさの奇妙な光が彼についてきた。
